Formation of a BiI 3 film on the Bi 2Se 3 substrate was observed via appearance of new LEED spots that closely corresponded to a √3 × √3-R30° superstructure, as shown in Fig. 1(b), in which the substrate and the adlayer spots are highlighted by the large and small hexagon, respectively. Epitaxial growth of BiI 3 on Bi 2Se 3 is feasible thanks to a close structural match between the bulk structures. Both crystal structures can be viewed as hexagonal close-packed arrangements of anions (either iodine or selenium) with cations (bismuth) occupying the octahedral voids in a regular fashion. In the tetradymite-type structure, like Bi 2Se 3, two consecutive rows of octahedral voids along the c axis are fully populated and each third row remains empty, thus forming a van der Waals (vdW) gap between the quintuple layers (QL),
